text: Welcome to our tutorial on text-to-image generation. Let’s get started! Suppose you want to generate an image of a dog sitting in the living room.
How does AI manage to do that?
Great question! Let's start by analyzing the description.
Perfect! Now that we've identified the key elements, let's focus on the dog. The AI is exposed to millions of images labelled with descriptions.
For example, it has seen many pictures of dogs in various positions such as “sitting”, “standing” and “ lying down.
Over time, it learns the features of a sitting dog: when a dog is sitting, its hind legs are bent, and its front legs are extended.
Interesting! So it understands the action associated with the word.
Exactly! It places the dog within the living room context, arranging elements like sofas, coffee tables, and rugs based on what it learned from numerous images.
Here is an example of the living room concept AI will learn after seeing many images.
It seems complicated. Does the AI use all the elements?
No, the AI prioritizes based on your description. The more specific you are, the closer the result matches your vision. Let's make your description more detailed.
Awesome! If we compare this new image with the previously generated one, you can see clearly how the AI incorporates additional elements mentioned in the description into the output.
You can also experiment with the different descriptions below to see how they affect the output image.
That’s fun! But why is the first dog sitting on the rug instead of the sofa as mentioned in the description?
Sometimes, when there are many details, the AI prioritizes what it thinks are the most important elements, which might mean missing some other information.
However, each generation process can be different. Try generating again, and you might see the dog on the sofa.
That makes sense. I’ll keep experimenting with descriptions to see what works best.
